title: Asymptotic Estimation, Interpolation and Extrapolation

Continuity estimation diversity around actual sample size guaranteed.  non-integer orders, things get complicated. divent, asymptotic entropy estimated unveiled jackknife estimator rarefied actual sample size. reason correspond exactly observed entropy. asymptotic richness less robust part estimation thus adjusted iteratively rarefied entropy equals actual sample’s entropy, ensuring continuity interpolation extrapolation. default arguments functions apply strategy, except Simpson’s diversity (\(q=2\)) estimated directly without bias.
code: # Actual sample coverage coverage(paracou_6_abd[1, ]) ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   site      weight estimator  coverage ##   <chr>      <dbl> <chr>         <dbl> ## 1 subplot_1   1.56 ZhangHuang    0.911 # Diversity at half the sample size (interpolated) paracou6_1_size <- abd_sum(paracou_6_abd[1, ], as_numeric = TRUE) div_hill(paracou_6_abd[1, ], q = 1, level = round(paracou6_1_size / 2)) ## # A tibble: 1 × 6 ##   site      weight estimator     order level diversity ##   <chr>      <dbl> <chr>         <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 subplot_1   1.56 Interpolation     1   471      67.6 # Sample size corresponding to 90% coverage coverage_to_size(paracou_6_abd[1, ], sample_coverage = 0.9) ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   site      weight sample_coverage  size ##   <chr>      <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 subplot_1   1.56             0.9   819 # Diversity at 90% sample coverage div_hill(paracou_6_abd[1, ], q = 1, level = 0.9) ## # A tibble: 1 × 6 ##   site      weight estimator     order level diversity ##   <chr>      <dbl> <chr>         <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 subplot_1   1.56 Interpolation     1   819      75.4 # Simpson diversity at levels from 0.9 to 1.1 times the sample size accum_hill(   paracou_6_abd[1, ],   q = 2,   levels = round(0.9 * paracou6_1_size):round(1.1 * paracou6_1_size)) %>%    autoplot()

title: Asymptotic Estimation, Interpolation and Extrapolation
text: iNEXT (Hsieh, Ma, Chao 2016) designed primarily interpolate extrapolate diversity integer orders. Extrapolation diversity order 0 relies Chao1 estimator richness order 1 uses Chao-Jost estimator. divent, extrapolation relies estimation asymptotic distribution community asymptotic richness entropy asymptotic distribution rarefied observed sample size equals observed entropy data. approach allows consistent estimation extrapolated diversity integer non-integer orders, thus allowing consistent diversity profiles without discontinuities \(q=0\) \(q=1\). results iNEXT can obtained forcing argument estimator = "ChaoJost". Small differences due different estimators sample coverage: divent uses accurate ZhangHuang estimator default. Last, confidence intervals diversity accumulation assume normality iNEXT: estimation variance estimated bootstrap confidence interval defined \(\pm 1.96\) times standard deviation. divent, confidence intervals built directly quantiles bootstrapped estimations.
code: library("iNEXT") data(spider) # Extrapolated diversity of an example dataset estimateD(spider$Girdled, level=300) ##   Assemblage   m        Method Order.q        SC        qD    qD.LCL    qD.UCL ## 1       data 300 Extrapolation       0 0.9579518 33.317733 25.804082 40.831384 ## 2       data 300 Extrapolation       1 0.9579518 12.869603 10.314593 15.424612 ## 3       data 300 Extrapolation       2 0.9579518  7.983882  5.993923  9.973841 # Similar estimation by divent div_hill(spider$Girdled, q = 0, level = 300, estimator = "ChaoJost") ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   estimator order level diversity ##   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 jackknife     0   300      33.5 div_hill(spider$Girdled, q = 1, level = 300, estimator = "ChaoJost") ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   estimator order level diversity ##   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 Chao2015      1   300      13.1 # Estimation at order 2 is explicit, with no optional choice div_hill(spider$Girdled, q = 2, level = 300) ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   estimator order level diversity ##   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 Chao2014      2   300      7.98 # Default estimation of divent div_hill(spider$Girdled, q = 0, level = 300) ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   estimator order level diversity ##   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 jackknife     0   300      33.5 div_hill(spider$Girdled, q = 1, level = 300) ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   estimator order level diversity ##   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 Chao2015      1   300      13.1

code: library("stats") plot(   tree.hclust <- hclust(     as.dist(species_dist),      method = "average"   ),    hang = -0.01,    axes = F ) axis(2) tree.hclust$height ## [1] 1 2

title: Phylogenies in divent
text: Conversion phylo object straightforward.  Edge lengths divided 2 conversion, documented ?.phylo.hclust. suit needs. divent, edge lengths multiplied 2 conversion, phylo objects can identical phylogenies.
code: library("ape") plot(tree.phylo <- as.phylo(tree.hclust)) axis(1) tree.phylo$edge.length ## [1] 1.0 0.5 0.5 0.5 tree.phylo$edge.length <- 2 * tree.phylo$edge.length plot(tree.phylo) axis(1)

title: Phylogenies in divent
text: last conversion phylo phylog.  Edge lengths stored directly phylog objects. $droot component keeps distances tips root. $Wdist component dist (half distance matrix without zero-diagonal) whose values \(d_{s,t}=\sqrt{2 \delta_{s,t}^2}\), \(\delta_{s,t}\) distance species \(s\) ant \(t\). phylog trees supported divent converted hclust:
code: library("ade4") plot(tree.phylog <- hclust2phylog(tree.hclust)) axis(1) tree.phylog$droot ##    C    A    B Int1 Root  ##    2    2    2    1    0 tree.phylog$Wdist^2/2 ##   C A ## A 2   ## B 2 1 tree2.hclust <- stats::hclust(tree.phylog$Wdist^2 / 2, "average") plot(tree2.hclust, hang = -0.01, axes = F) axis(2)

title: Phylogenies in divent
text: function as_phylo_divent converts object one previous types.  plot method dendrogram objects. phylo_divent tree list. contains: $phylo: tree phylo object. $hclust: tree hclust object. $height: height tree. $cuts: heights nodes tree. $intervals: intervals cuts. $phylo_groups: matrix describes ancestors species interval. column names give recent cut interval. Values group present species belongs interval. example , species B belong group interval starting 1.
code: library("divent") plot(tree.phylo_divent <- as_phylo_divent(tree.phylo)) axis(2) tree.phylo_divent ## $phylo ##  ## Phylogenetic tree with 3 tips and 2 internal nodes. ##  ## Tip labels: ##   A, B, C ##  ## Rooted; includes branch lengths. ##  ## $hclust ##  ## Call: ## ape::as.hclust.phylo(x = tree) ##  ## Cluster method   : unknown  ## Number of objects: 3  ##  ##  ## $height ## [1] 2 ##  ## $cuts ## [1] 1 2 ##  ## $intervals ## [1] 1 1 ##  ## $phylo_groups ##   0 1 ## A 1 1 ## B 2 1 ## C 3 2 ##  ## attr(,"class") ## [1] "phylo_divent"

title: Spatially Explicit Simpson's Entropy — ent_sp_simpson
text: X spatialized community (dbmss::wmppp object PointType values species names.) r vector distances. title: Spatially Explicit Simpson's Entropy — ent_sp_simpson

title: Deformed exponential — exp_q
text: deformed exponential reciprocal deformed logarithm Tsallis1994divent, see ln_q. defined \((x(1-q)+1)^{\frac{1}{(1-q)}}\). \(q>1\), \(\ln_q{(+\infty)}=\frac{1}{(q-1)}\) \(\exp_q{(x)}\) defined \(x>\frac{1}{(q-1)}\).

title: Probabilities of Species — probabilities
text: x object. may : numeric vector containing abundances. may named track species names. object class species_distribution. ... Unused. estimator One estimators probability distribution: "naive" (default value), "Chao2013", "Chao2015", "ChaoShen" estimate probabilities observed species asymptotic distribution. unveiling One possible unveiling methods estimate probabilities unobserved species: "none" (default, species added), "uniform" (unobserved species probability) "geometric" (unobserved species distribution geometric). richness_estimator estimator richness evaluate total number species. title: Probabilities of Species — probabilities
text: probabilities() estimates probability distribution sample. estimator "naive", observed abundance distribution used estimate actual probability distribution. list species changed: zero-abundance species cleared, unobserved species added. First, observed species probabilities estimated following Chao2003;textualdivent, .e. input probabilities multiplied sample coverage, according sophisticated models: Chao2013;textualdivent, single-parameter model, Chao2015;textualdivent, two-parameter model. total probability observed species equals sample coverage. , distribution unobserved species can unveiled: number estimated according richness_estimator. coverage deficit (1 minus sample coverage) shared unobserved species equally (unveiling = "uniform", Chao2013divent) according geometric distribution (unveiling = "geometric", Chao2015divent).

title: Random communities — rcommunity
text: Communities fixed size drawn multinomial distribution according distribution probabilities provided prob. abundance vector abd may used instead probabilities, size default total number individuals vector. Random communities can built drawing multinomial law following Marcon2012a;textualdivent, trying estimate distribution actual community as_probabilities. bootstrap "Chao2013", distribution estimated single parameter model unobserved species given equal probabilities. bootstrap "Chao2015", two-parameter model used unobserved species follow geometric distribution. Alternatively, probabilities may drawn following classical distribution: either lognormal ("lnorm")  Preston1948divent given standard deviation (sd_lnorm; note mean actually normalizing constant. value set equal 0 simulation normal distribution unnormalized log-abundances), log-series ("lseries") Fisher1943divent parameter alpha, geometric ("geom") Motomura1932divent parameter prob_geom, broken stick ("bstick") MacArthur1957divent. number simulated species fixed species_number, except "lseries" obtained alpha size: \(S = \alpha \ln(1 + size / \alpha)\). Note probabilities drawn . number communities draw, n, greater 1, drawn multinomial distribution following probabilities. Log-normal, log-series broken-stick distributions stochastic. geometric distribution completely determined parameters. Spatialized communities include location individuals window, dbmss::wmppp object. Several point processes available, namely binomial (points uniformly distributed window) Thomas1949;textualdivent, clustered. Point weights, may instance size trees forest community, can uniform, follow Weibull negative exponential distribution. latter describe well diameter distribution trees forest Rennolls1985,Turner2004divent.
